page.title: 15LOCAL HISTORY
page.content: The name of the village Drayton Bassett, mentioned in the original Domesday Book, comes from the Norman Turstine de Bassett in passession in 1086. The name 'Bassett' was added to distinguish it from other Draytons. The Bassett line died in 1390. The village is associated with the Peel family. Robert Peel the elder bought the estate in 1790,having made his fortune in the cotton textile industry in Bury, Lancashire. He became a local benefactor providing schools, church and the Swiss style cottages for his estate workers in the village. 6 generations of the Peel family lived in Drayton Manor,including Sir Robert,Prime Minister, founder of Metropolitan police (1829) responsible for the Tamworth Manifesto (1834) outlining future conservative party policy. This association ended in 1934.
